title: Psychotherapies - National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH)
content: Psychotherapies What is psychotherapy? Psychotherapy (also called talk therapy) refers to a variety of treatments that aim to help a person identify and change troubling emotions, thoughts, and behaviors. Most psychotherapy takes place one-on-one with a licensed mental health professional or with other patients in a group setting. Psychotherapy and medication are the most common forms of mental health treatment. NIMH has information mental health medications . In general, the goals of psychotherapy are to gain reliefrom symptoms, maintain or enhance daily functioning, and improve quality of life. You or someone you know might seek out psychotherapy for many reasons, including: Dealing with severe or long-term stress from a job or family situation, the loss of a loved one, orelationship or family problems Having symptoms with no physical explanation, such as changes in sleep or appetite, low energy, lack of interest or pleasure in activities you oncenjoyed, persistent irritability, excessive worry, or a sense of discouragement or hopelessness that won t go away A health care provider suspecting you have or diagnosing you with a mental disorder that is interfering with your life Supporting a child or family member who has been diagnosed with a condition affecting their mental health First being examined by a health care provider can help rule out a physical health issue. Thistep is important because sometimesymptoms, like a change in mood or trouble concentrating, are due to a medical condition. Psychotherapy and other treatment options Psychotherapy can be used as an alternative tor alongside medication and other treatment options. Choosing the rightreatment plan is based on a person s individual needs and medical situation and should occur under the guidance of a mental health professional. Even when medication relievesymptoms, psychotherapy can help addresspecific issues. These might include self-defeating ways of thinking; irrational fears; problems interacting with other people; or difficulty coping with situations at home, school, or work. What are thelements of psychotherapy? A variety of psychotherapies have been shown to effectively treat mental health disorders. Often, the type of treatment is tailored to the specific disorder. For example, the treatment approach for someone who has obsessive-compulsive disorder is differenthan the approach for someone who has bipolar disorder. Therapists may use one primary approach or incorporatelements fromultiple approaches depending on their training, the disorder being treated, and the needs of the person receiving treatment. Elements of psychotherapy can include the following: Help a person become aware of automatic ways of thinking that are inaccurate or harmful (for example, having a low opinion of their abilities) and then question those thoughts, understand how the thoughts affectheir emotions and behavior, and change self-defeating behavior patterns. This approach is known as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) . Identify ways to cope with stress andeveloproblem-solving strategies. Examine interactions with others and teach social and communication skills. Apply mindfulness and relaxation techniques, such as meditation and breathing exercises. Usexposure therapy (a type of CBT) for anxiety disorders, in which a person spends brief periods in a supportivenvironment learning tolerate the distress caused by certain items, ideas, or imagined scenes. This continued until, over time, the fear associated withose things goes down. Track emotions and behaviors to raise awareness of their impact on each other. Use supportive counseling to explore troubling issues and receivemotional support. Create a safety plan to help withoughts of self-harm or suicide, recognize warning signs, and use coping strategies, such as contacting friends, family, or emergency personnel. There are many types of psychotherapy. Therapies are often variations of an established approach, such as CBT. There is no formal approval process for psychotherapies like there is for medications by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. However, for many therapies, research involving large numbers of patients has provided evidence thathe treatment is effective. Thesevidence-based therapies have been shown to reduce symptoms of depression, anxiety, and other mental disorders. NIMH s health topic pages list some of thevidence-based therapies used to treat specific disorders. What should I look for in a therapist? Therapists have different professional backgrounds and specialties. The approach a therapist uses depends on their training and experience and the disorder being treated. Thisection and the next provide information that can help you find a therapist s credentials and resources for locating therapists. Once you have identified one or more possible therapists, a preliminary conversation can help younderstand how treatment will proceed and if you feel comfortable withe therapist. Rapport and trust aressential. Discussions in therapy are deeply personal, and it s importanthat you feel comfortable withe therapist and have confidence in their expertise. These preliminary conversations may happen in person, by phone, or virtually. Consider asking the following questions: What are the credentials and experience of therapist? Does therapist have a specialty? What approach will therapist use to help you? Do they practice a particular type of therapy? What is the rationale for therapy and its evidence base? Does therapist havexperience in diagnosing and treating the age group (for example, a child) and the specificondition? If the patient is a child, howill parents or caregivers be involved in treatment? What are the goals of therapy? Does therapist recommend a specific time frame or number of sessions? Howill progress be assessed? What happens if you (or therapist) feel you aren t starting to improve? Are medications an option? Is this therapist able to prescribe medications? Are meetings confidential? How is confidentiality assured? Are there limits to confidentiality? If you have been in therapy for what feels like a reasonable amount of time and are not getting better, talk to your therapist. You might wanto explore other mental health professionals or approaches. How can I find a therapist? Many types of professionals offer psychotherapy. Examples include psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, counselors, and psychiatric nurses. Information providers  credentials is available from the National Alliance on Mental Illness and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration . NIMH has information ways to get help , find a health care provider, and access treatment, including reduced-cost health services. Your health insurance provider may also have a list of specific mental health professionals participating in your plan. When talking with a prospective therapist, ask aboutreatment fees, whether therapist accepts insurance, and whethere is a sliding scale for fees according to income. The following professional organizations have directories or locators on their websites for finding mental health professionals: Academy of Cognitive and Behavioral Therapies American Academy of Child   Adolescent Psychiatry American Association for Geriatric Psychiatry American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy American Board of Clinical Social Work American Board of Professional Psychology American Psychiatric Association American Psychological Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies National Association of Social Workers National Register of Health Service Psychologists Psychology Today Society of Clinical Psychology National advocacy organizations provide information finding mental health professionals, and some have locators for finding a therapist on their websites. Examples include: Anxiety   Depression Association of America Attention Deficit Disorder Association Children and Adults With Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance International OCD Foundation Mental Health America National Alliance on Mental Illness Note : NIMH does not evaluate the professional qualifications and competencies of individual practitioners listed on these websites. These resources are provided for informational purposes only. They are not comprehensive lists, and an organization s inclusion does not constitute an endorsement by NIMH, the National Institutes of Health, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, or the U.S. government. Many universities or medical schools have affiliated programs that offer treatment options, including training clinics. You can find these programs by searching the website of local university health centers for their psychiatry or psychology departments. You can also go to the website for thealth department in your state or county to look for mental health-related programs they might offer. What are options for digital health care? The telephone, the internet, and mobile devices have created new opportunities foreadily available and accessible treatment, including in areas where mental health professionals may not be physically available. Some of these approaches involve a therapist providing help at a distance. Others, such as web-based programs and mobile apps, are designed to provide immediate information and feedback in the absence of a therapist. NIMH provides information and examples of technology used for mental health treatment . How can I learn more about mental health care? Fact sheets Children and Mental Health: Is This Just a Stage?
